Knowledge Point: \is{Constituent order}The predicate may also come first. This happens only when the subject is well-es\-tab\-lished, i.e. topical\is{Topic, topicality} in discourse; it tends to be expressed by a pronoun as in \REF{ex:9.4}, or a generic noun phrase as in \REF{ex:9.5}. In this construction, the predicate is prominent. In \REF{ex:9.5}, for example, the predicate conveys unexpected, surprising information.
Content 1: \gll E ai rō \ꞌā e tahi taŋata tire, \textbf{he} \textbf{piroto} \textbf{\ꞌavione} a ia. | \gls IPFV exist EMPH IDENT NUM one person Chile PRED pilot airplane PROP 3SG | \glt ‘There was one Chilean, he was an airplane pilot.’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{He} \textbf{taŋata} tau manu era, \textbf{he} \textbf{poki} \textbf{\ꞌa} \textbf{Uho} tau manu era. | \gls PRED person DEM bird DIST PRED child of.A Uho DEM bird DIST | \glt ‘That bird was a human being, that bird was Uho’s child.’
Content 3: \gll \textbf{He} \textbf{taŋata} tau manu era, \textbf{he} \textbf{poki} \textbf{\ꞌa} \textbf{Uho} tau manu era. | \gls PRED person DEM bird DIST PRED child of.A Uho DEM bird DIST | \glt ‘That bird was a human being, that bird was Uho’s child.’

Knowledge Point: In \REF{ex:9.6}, Tangaroa (who has transformed himself into a seal, and is mistaken for a seal by the people) wants to emphasise that he is the king, not a real seal as the people think. The predicate \textit{he {\ꞌ}ariki} is counterexpectative and occurs before the subject.\footnote{\label{fn:460}Notice that ko Taŋaroa, which is an apposition\is{Apposition} to the predicate, is not fronted but remains in its post-subject position; see sec. \sectref{sec:9.2.5} for more examples of split predicates.}
Content 1: \gll He raŋi mai te re\ꞌo o te pakia: ‘\textbf{He} \textbf{\ꞌariki} au ko Taŋaroa’. | \gls NTR call hither ART voice of ART seal PRED king 1SG PROM Tangaroa | \glt ‘The voice of the seal cried: I am king Tangaroa.’

Knowledge Point: As both noun phrases are referential\is{Referentiality} and definite\is{Definiteness}, and both refer to the same entity, it is not always clear which NP is subject and which is predicate. Constituent order\is{Constituent order} cannot be used as the sole criterion, as both subject and predicate of a nominal clause\is{Clause!nominal} may come first.\footnote{\label{fn:461}See examples (\ref{ex:9.1}–\ref{ex:9.6}) in classifying clauses\is{Clause!classifying}; the same is true in other types of nominal clauses\is{Clause!nominal}, e.g. locative clauses (\sectref{sec:9.4.1}).} It is even questionable whether the term predicate is appropriate at all in identifying clauses\is{Clause!identifying} (see \citealt[440]{Anderson2004}): as both noun phrases are referential expressions, they are fundamentally different from predicates, which designate properties or events rather than referring to entities.
Content 1: \gll A Thor Heyerdahl he científico e tahi. | \gls PROP Thor Heyerdahl NTR scientist NUM one | \glt ‘Thor Heyerdahl was a scientist.’
Content 2: \gll He raŋi mai te re\ꞌo o te pakia: ‘\textbf{He} \textbf{\ꞌariki} au ko Taŋaroa’. | \gls NTR call hither ART voice of ART seal PRED king 1SG PROM Tangaroa | \glt ‘The voice of the seal cried: I am king Tangaroa.’

Knowledge Point: Even so, the terms subject and predicate may be used in identifying clauses\is{Clause!identifying} in a loose way, in the sense that the subject is the entity to be identified, and the predicate is the identifying expression. In some cases it is clear which NP is the subject, as this NP functions as discourse topic\is{Topic, topicality}. In other cases, however, it is difficult to identify subject and predicate – unless we adopt a simple syntactic definition. As indicated above, in every identifying clause one noun phrase is marked with ko, while the other is an unmarked NP. Taking the ko{}-marked NP as predicate provides a simple criterion. Moreover, this analysis coincides with the intuitive assignment of subject and predicate in those cases where the distinction is clear: in examples like \REF{ex:9.11}, it is clear that the unmarked NP is subject, while the ko-marked NP serves to identify this subject.
Content 1: \gll Te ŋāŋata mātāmu\ꞌa o Rapa Nui ko te \ꞌariki era ko Hotu Matu\ꞌa ananake ko tō\ꞌona hua\ꞌai. | \gls ART men first of Rapa Nui PROM ART king DIST PROM Hotu Matu’a together PROM POSS.3SG.O family | \glt ‘The first people of Rapa Nui were king Hotu Matu’a with his family.’

Knowledge Point: In \REF{ex:9.14} above, the pronoun is not marked with ko when the other constituent is a proper noun. There are also a few cases in the corpus where a pronoun and a proper noun are both ko{}-marked. Two examples are provided below:
Content 1: \gll A au \textbf{ko} \textbf{Omoaŋa}. | \gls PROP 1SG PROM Omoanga | \glt ‘I am Omoanga.’

Knowledge Point: If the pronoun is taken as the subject, these clauses are counterexamples to the claim that only the predicate is marked with ko. However, a different analysis is also possible: the pronoun can be analysed as the predicate (with implicit subject), with the proper noun added as apposition\is{Apposition}, ‘It’s me, Totimo’. In both examples above this analysis is plausible. In \REF{ex:9.17}, for example, the situation is as follows: there is a blind girl, Mahina Tea, who knows a boy called Totimo. Totimo walks up to her, embraces her and utters the clause quoted here. An analysis as predicate + apposition\is{Apposition} is appropriate here.\footnote{\label{fn:463}This analysis is reinforced by the fact that in some cases the two constituents are separated by a comma:
Content 1: \gll Ko au ko Totimo. | \gls PROM 1SG PROM Totimo | \glt ‘I am Totimo.’

Knowledge Point: To give an example, in the context preceding \REF{ex:9.20} above, there has been no mention of the son of the sun and the high God, so the hearer does not necessarily know that there is such a person as the child of the sun, or that the people in the story had a high God at all. Therefore, this person is not accessible to the hearer. By contrast, in \REF{ex:9.23}, ‘those witches’ refers to witches who have been mentioned earlier in the story; the identifying clause enables the hearer to identify this known entity with the subject ‘those people’. Similarly, in \REF{ex:9.24} the speaker refers to a type of fishing line which he assumes to be known by the hearer (even though it has not been mentioned in the text itself).
Content 1: \gll A Tiki \textbf{he} \textbf{poki} o te ra\ꞌā \ꞌe \textbf{he} \textbf{\ꞌatua} \textbf{rahi} o rāua. | \gls PROP Tiki PRED child of ART sun and PRED god great of 3PL | \glt ‘Tiki was the son of the sun and their high God.’
Content 2: \gll He \ꞌite ia Tu\ꞌu Koihu \ꞌi tū hora era tū ŋā nu\ꞌu era \textbf{ko} \textbf{tū} \textbf{ŋā} \textbf{tahutahu} \textbf{era}. | \gls NTR know then Tu’u Koihu at DEM time DIST DEM PL people DIST PROM DEM PL witch DIST | \glt ‘At that moment Tu’u Koihu knew that those people (whom he saw) were those witches.’
Content 3: \gll Te hau era, ho\ꞌi, e hī era \textbf{ko} \textbf{te} \textbf{ŋā} \textbf{hau} \textbf{hiro} \textbf{era} e toru kave. | \gls ART cord DIST indeed IPFV to_fish DIST PROM ART PL cord braid DIST NUM three fibre | \glt ‘(in a description of fishing techniques:) The lines they fished with, were those lines braided with three strands.’

Knowledge Point: The referent of a noun phrase in an identifying clause must not only be unique and accessible\is{Accessibility}, it also needs to be a specific\is{Specific reference}, bounded entity. In the following two examples, the predicate noun phrase could be considered as unique and accessible; nevertheless, it is marked with he\is{he (nominal predicate marker)}, i.e. the construction is a classifying clause\is{Clause!classifying}. In \REF{ex:9.25}, the noun phrase refers to priests in general, not to any specific priest. Likewise, in \REF{ex:9.26}, the reference is to adults in general.\footnote{\label{fn:466}These examples are cleft\is{Cleft} constructions, which are discussed in more detail in sec. \sectref{sec:9.2.6} below.}
Content 1: \gll \textbf{He} \textbf{ivi\ꞌatua} \textbf{nō} te kope era e puā era \ꞌi te ta\ꞌu era i a ia te \ꞌao. | \gls PRED priest just ART person DIST IPFV touch DIST at ART year DIST at PROP 3SG ART reign | \glt ‘The priest was the only person (lit. only the priest was the person) who would touch him (te bird man) in the year in which he reigned.’
Content 2: \gll Te ŋā poki ko \ꞌite \ꞌana o ruŋa i te me\ꞌe ta\ꞌato\ꞌa o te naonao \ꞌe \textbf{he} \textbf{pa\ꞌari} te me\ꞌe i ta\ꞌe \ꞌite. | \gls ART PL child PRF know CONT of above at ART thing all of ART mosquito and PRED adult ART thing PFV CONNEG know | \glt ‘The children know everything about the mosquitoes, and the adults are the ones who don’t know.’

Knowledge Point: The order of constituents in an identifying clause depends to some extent on the type of noun phrases involved. When both constituents are common noun phrases, the predicate usually occurs after the subject, as illustrated in (\ref{ex:9.23}–\ref{ex:9.24}) and \REF{ex:9.11} above. The predicate may come first when it conveys significant and possibly surprising information as in \REF{ex:9.27}, or when it is a discourse topic established in the preceding context as in \REF{ex:9.28}.\footnote{\label{fn:467}Cf. \citet{Levinsohn2007}: prominence may involve both new information (focal prominence) and established information (thematic\is{Thematicity} prominence).}
Content 1: \gll He \ꞌite ia Tu\ꞌu Koihu \ꞌi tū hora era tū ŋā nu\ꞌu era \textbf{ko} \textbf{tū} \textbf{ŋā} \textbf{tahutahu} \textbf{era}. | \gls NTR know then Tu’u Koihu at DEM time DIST DEM PL people DIST PROM DEM PL witch DIST | \glt ‘At that moment Tu’u Koihu knew that those people (whom he saw) were those witches.’
Content 2: \gll Te hau era, ho\ꞌi, e hī era \textbf{ko} \textbf{te} \textbf{ŋā} \textbf{hau} \textbf{hiro} \textbf{era} e toru kave. | \gls ART cord DIST indeed IPFV to_fish DIST PROM ART PL cord braid DIST NUM three fibre | \glt ‘(in a description of fishing techniques:) The lines they fished with, were those lines braided with three strands.’
Content 3: \gll Te ŋāŋata mātāmu\ꞌa o Rapa Nui ko te \ꞌariki era ko Hotu Matu\ꞌa ananake ko tō\ꞌona hua\ꞌai. | \gls ART men first of Rapa Nui PROM ART king DIST PROM Hotu Matu’a together PROM POSS.3SG.O family | \glt ‘The first people of Rapa Nui were king Hotu Matu’a with his family.’
Content 4: \gll Ta\ꞌe he \ꞌatua tau me\ꞌe era, he taŋata; \textbf{ko} \textbf{te} \textbf{ŋā} \textbf{io} \textbf{era} \textbf{\ꞌĀmai} tau me\ꞌe era. | \gls CONNEG PRED god DEM thing DIST PRED person PROM ART PL youngster DIST Amai DEM thing DIST | \glt ‘These beings are not gods, they are men; these beings are the Amai guys.’
Content 5: \gll \textbf{Ko} \textbf{te} \textbf{me\ꞌe} \textbf{nei} te me\ꞌe u\ꞌi rahi o te mu\ꞌa \ꞌā. | \gls PROM ART thing PROX ART thing see much of ART front IDENT | \glt ‘This (= the difficulties mentioned in the previous clause) was something often seen in the past.’

Knowledge Point: When the identifying clause contains a pronoun (whether subject or predicate), this is always in an initial position, as illustrated in (\ref{ex:9.13}–\ref{ex:9.14}) above.
Content 1: \gll Pero \textbf{ko} \textbf{au} te suerekao o te hora nei. | \gls but PROM 1SG ART governor of ART time PROX | \glt ‘But I am the governor now (or: the governor now is me).’
Content 2: \gll A au \textbf{ko} \textbf{Omoaŋa}. | \gls PROP 1SG PROM Omoanga | \glt ‘I am Omoanga.’

Knowledge Point: When the clause consists of a proper noun and a common noun phrase, they may occur in either order, as the following examples show. Putting the predicate before the subject gives it more prominence\is{Prominence}. In \REF{ex:9.31}, for example, the predicate ko Korikē is contrasted with other persons. In \REF{ex:9.32}, Anakena is singled out between other places on the island.
Content 1: \gll ¿\textbf{Ko} \textbf{Korikē} te me\ꞌe nei \ꞌo ko Titata? ... ¿\textbf{Ko} \textbf{Titata} te me\ꞌe nei? | \gls ~PROM Korike ART thing PROX or PROM Titata ~ ~PROM Titata ART thing PROX | \glt ‘(pointing at someone in a picture:) Is this Korike or Titata? Is it Titata?’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Ko} \textbf{\ꞌAnakena} \textbf{mau} \textbf{nō} te kona kai māuiui \ꞌā e noho mai ena. | \gls PROM Anakena really just ART place NEG.PFV sick CONT IPFV stay hither MED | \glt ‘Anakena was the only place where the people who lived there did not get sick.’

Knowledge Point: When a clause has a pronominal subject and the predicate comes first, certain postnominal modifiers of the predicate are placed after the subject. In \REF{ex:9.33}, \textit{\mbox{ō{\ꞌ}ou}} is a postnominal possessive modifying the predicate repahoa; it is separated from the nucleus by the subject au.
Content 1: \gll He repahoa nō \textbf{au} ō\ꞌou. | \gls PRED friend just 1SG POSS.2SG.O | \glt ‘I am just your friend.’

Knowledge Point: As discussed in \sectref{sec:4.6.6}, this process also takes place when the subject is a demonstrative pronoun; this is illustrated in (\ref{ex:9.35}–\ref{ex:9.36}) below. The stranded\is{Stranding} element is often a possessive as in \REF{ex:9.33}; it may also be a numeral as in \REF{ex:9.35}, or a relative clause\is{Clause!relative} as in \REF{ex:9.36}. While in \REF{ex:9.36} the relative clause as a whole is separated from the head noun famiria, in \REF{ex:9.37} the relative clause itself is split up: the verb phrase\is{Clause!relative} (\textit{aŋa mau {\ꞌ}ā}) moves along with the head noun, while the direct object is stranded after the subject (\sectref{sec:11.4.5} on raising of relative clause\is{Clause!relative} verbs).
Content 1: \gll He \ꞌa\ꞌamu nō \textbf{nei} e tahi... | \gls PRED story just PROX NUM one | \glt ‘This (what follows) is a story...’
Content 2: \gll Famiria hope\ꞌa \textbf{rā} oho mai mai kampō, mai \ꞌAnakena. | \gls family last DIST go hither from countryside from Anakena | \glt ‘This was the last family who came from the countryside, from Anakena.’
Content 3: \gll He repahoa nō \textbf{au} ō\ꞌou. | \gls PRED friend just 1SG POSS.2SG.O | \glt ‘I am just your friend.’
Content 4: \gll He \ꞌa\ꞌamu nō \textbf{nei} e tahi... | \gls PRED story just PROX NUM one | \glt ‘This (what follows) is a story...’
Content 5: \gll Famiria hope\ꞌa \textbf{rā} oho mai mai kampō, mai \ꞌAnakena. | \gls family last DIST go hither from countryside from Anakena | \glt ‘This was the last family who came from the countryside, from Anakena.’
Content 6: \gll Famiria hope\ꞌa \textbf{rā} oho mai mai kampō, mai \ꞌAnakena. | \gls family last DIST go hither from countryside from Anakena | \glt ‘This was the last family who came from the countryside, from Anakena.’
Content 7: \gll He vi\ꞌe \obaŋa mau \ꞌā\,\cb \textbf{a} \textbf{ia} \obi te me\ꞌe haŋa o te \ꞌAtua\,\cb. | \gls PRED woman {\db}do really IDENT PROP 3SG {\db}ACC ART thing want of ART God | \glt ‘She is a woman who really does the things God wants.’

Knowledge Point: The effect of relegating the verb to a relative clause\is{Clause!relative} is that the initial noun phrase is in focus\is{Focus}, while the event or action is backgrounded. Clefts are used when the event or action as such is presupposed; it has already been mentioned as in \REF{ex:9.41}, or can be inferred from the context: in \REF{ex:9.40}, the context of a musical contest presupposes that there is a winner, while the important new information is the identity of the winner. The act of winning is therefore backgrounded, while the noun phrase referring to the winner is put in focus.
Content 1: \gll Ko te ŋā me\ꞌe nei \obte me\ꞌe mo ai o te taŋata mo oho mo ruku o te hora nei\,\cb. | \gls PROM ART PL thing PROX {\db}ART thing for exist of ART person for go for dive of ART time PROX | \glt ‘These things (which have just been listed) are the things that people need to go diving nowadays.’
Content 2: \gll Ko te nūna\ꞌa era \ꞌa \ꞌŌrare \obte nūna\ꞌa i rē\,\cb. | \gls PROM ART group DIST of.A Orare {\db}ART group PFV win | \glt ‘(in a report about a music contest:) Orare’s group was the group that won.’

Knowledge Point: Classifying\is{Clause!classifying} cleft\is{Cleft} constructions are especially common with the verb haŋa ‘want’ and other expressions of volition\is{Verb!volition}/desire (\sectref{sec:3.2.3.1.1} on the nominal tendency of volition verbs). With these verbs, the noun phrase does not contain a full relative clause\is{Clause!relative}, but a bare modifying verb, such as haŋa in \REF{ex:9.45}; if the subject of this verb is expressed, it is a possessive pronoun (\textit{tā{\ꞌ}aku} in \REF{ex:9.45}) or a genitive phrase (\sectref{sec:11.4.4}):
Content 1: \gll \textbf{He} \textbf{kāpē} tā\ꞌaku me\ꞌe haŋa. | \gls PRED coffee POSS.1SG.A thing want | \glt ‘Coffee is what I want (lit. my thing want).’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{He} \textbf{kāpē} tā\ꞌaku me\ꞌe haŋa. | \gls PRED coffee POSS.1SG.A thing want | \glt ‘Coffee is what I want (lit. my thing want).’

Knowledge Point: As discussed in \sectref{sec:8.6.3}, the actor-emphatic\is{Actor-emphatic construction} (AE) construction also serves to put a noun phrase in focus\is{Focus}. It is not entirely clear which conditions determine the choice between an AE construction and a cleft\is{Cleft}. However, AE’s are only used to put agentive subjects in focus; in order to put non-agentive subjects in focus as in \REF{ex:9.41} or non-subjects as in \REF{ex:9.45}, only clefts can be used.
Content 1: \gll Ko te ŋā me\ꞌe nei \obte me\ꞌe mo ai o te taŋata mo oho mo ruku o te hora nei\,\cb. | \gls PROM ART PL thing PROX {\db}ART thing for exist of ART person for go for dive of ART time PROX | \glt ‘These things (which have just been listed) are the things that people need to go diving nowadays.’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{He} \textbf{kāpē} tā\ꞌaku me\ꞌe haŋa. | \gls PRED coffee POSS.1SG.A thing want | \glt ‘Coffee is what I want (lit. my thing want).’

Knowledge Point: The predicate may be marked with he\is{he (nominal predicate marker)} as in \REF{ex:9.47}, in which case the clause is a classifying clause\is{Clause!classifying} (\sectref{sec:9.2.1}). This is rare, though; usually the predicate is a bare noun phrase, lacking any determiner.
Content 1: \gll Te \ꞌati ena o te kahu \ꞌi rā noho iŋa \textbf{he} \textbf{\ꞌati} nuinui e tahi. | \gls ART problem MED of ART clothes at DIST stay NMLZ PRED problem big:RED NUM one | \glt ‘The problem of clothing at the time was a big one.’

Knowledge Point: These examples show that, as in other nominal clauses\is{Clause!nominal}, either the subject may come first as in \REF{ex:9.47} and \REF{ex:9.49}, or the predicate as in \REF{ex:9.48} and \REF{ex:9.50}.
Content 1: \gll Te \ꞌati ena o te kahu \ꞌi rā noho iŋa \textbf{he} \textbf{\ꞌati} nuinui e tahi. | \gls ART problem MED of ART clothes at DIST stay NMLZ PRED problem big:RED NUM one | \glt ‘The problem of clothing at the time was a big one.’
Content 2: \gll Māuiui nei \textbf{me\ꞌe} rakerake, me\ꞌe pe\ꞌe. | \gls sick PROX thing bad:RED thing infect | \glt ‘This disease was serious, it was contagious.’
Content 3: \gll \textbf{Taŋata} \ꞌuri\ꞌuri te taŋata nei \ꞌe \textbf{taŋata} rakerake. | \gls person black:RED ART person PROX and person bad:RED | \glt ‘This man is dark and ugly.’
Content 4: \gll \textbf{Me\ꞌe} \ꞌiti\ꞌiti koe \ꞌi roto i te vaikava. \textbf{Me\ꞌe} nuinui koe mō\ꞌoku... | \gls thing small:RED 2SG at inside at ART ocean thing big:RED 2SG BEN.1SG.O | \glt ‘You are a little thing in the ocean. You are big to me...’

Knowledge Point: In the examples above, the property is an adjective. It may also be another type of noun modifier: a verbal clause as in (\ref{ex:9.51}–\ref{ex:9.52}), or a modifying noun as in \REF{ex:9.53}.
Content 1: \gll Me\ꞌe ta\ꞌe kai kōkoma moa māua. | \gls thing CONNEG eat intestines chicken 1DU.EXCL | \glt ‘We (are people who) don’t eat chicken intestines.’
Content 2: \gll Toko\ꞌa, a Manutara, me\ꞌe vara unu i te \ꞌava. | \gls also PROP Manutara thing usually drink ACC ART liquor | \glt ‘Also, Manutara was (someone who was) given to drinking liquor.’
Content 3: \gll \ꞌE henua nei, henua ma\ꞌuŋa rahi. | \gls and land PROX land mountain many | \glt ‘And this land is a land of many mountains.’

Knowledge Point: As (\ref{ex:9.51}–\ref{ex:9.52}) show, the modifying verb may be preceded by preverbal particles, including the negator \textit{ta{\ꞌ}e}\is{tae (negator)@ta{\ꞌ}e (negator)}.
Content 1: \gll Me\ꞌe ta\ꞌe kai kōkoma moa māua. | \gls thing CONNEG eat intestines chicken 1DU.EXCL | \glt ‘We (are people who) don’t eat chicken intestines.’
Content 2: \gll Toko\ꞌa, a Manutara, me\ꞌe vara unu i te \ꞌava. | \gls also PROP Manutara thing usually drink ACC ART liquor | \glt ‘Also, Manutara was (someone who was) given to drinking liquor.’

Knowledge Point: This construction is unusual in that both noun phrases seem to be marked as a nominal predicate. However, a more plausible analysis is also possible: the construction may be a subjectless attributive clause, in which the predicate \textit{\mbox{me{\ꞌ}e} X} is followed by an apposition\is{Apposition} introduced by he\is{he (nominal predicate marker)}. \REF{ex:9.56} could be paraphrased as ‘It’s (a) mortal (thing), man is.’ This appositional analysis is suggested by the use of he (see \sectref{sec:5.12.1} for the use of he in appositions\is{Apposition}), and by the fact that the he{}-marked NP always occurs after the \is{mee ‘thing’@me{\ꞌ}e ‘thing’}\textit{me{\ꞌ}e} phrase.
Content 1: \gll Me\ꞌe mate he taŋata. | \gls thing die PRED person | \glt ‘Man is mortal.’

Knowledge Point: However, ai\is{ai ‘to exist’} is used with other aspectuals as well, for example neutral he \REF{ex:9.64} and exhortative\is{Exhortative} e \REF{ex:9.65}:
Content 1: \gll \ꞌI tō\ꞌona mahana \textbf{he} \textbf{ai} mai te aŋa he \ꞌāua titi, \ꞌo he rau kato... | \gls at POSS.3SG.O day NTR exist hither ART work PRED fence build or PRED leaf pick | \glt ‘On some days there was work: building fences or picking leaves...’
Content 2: \gll Mo oho e tahi taŋata ki tai, \textbf{e} \textbf{ai} te me\ꞌe ta\ꞌato\ꞌa o te hī. | \gls if go NUM one person to sea EXH exist ART thing all of ART to_fish | \glt ‘If someone goes to the sea, he needs all the fishing gear (lit. there should be all the things of fishing).’

Knowledge Point: Just like plain existential clauses\is{Clause!existential}, existential-locative clauses may be either verbless as in (\ref{ex:9.66}–\ref{ex:9.67}) or verbal as in (\ref{ex:9.68}–\ref{ex:9.69}). In older texts, they are always verbless.
Content 1: \gll He taote e tahi \textbf{\ꞌi} \textbf{muri} \textbf{i} \textbf{a} \textbf{ia}. | \gls PRED doctor NUM one at near at PROP 3SG | \glt ‘There was a doctor with her.’
Content 2: \gll He taŋata \textbf{to} \textbf{nei}... Ŋata Vake te \ꞌīŋoa. | \gls PRED person ART:of PROX Ngata Vake ART name | \glt ‘There was a man here, called Ngata Vake.’
Content 3: \gll ¿E ai rō \ꞌā te ika \textbf{o} \textbf{roto}? | \gls ~IPFV exist EMPH CONT ART fish of inside | \glt ‘Are there fish inside (the net)?’
Content 4: \gll ¡\ꞌĀhani \ꞌō e ai rō \ꞌā te hare hāpī mā\ꞌohi \textbf{o} \textbf{nei}! | \gls ~if_only really IPFV exist EMPH CONT ART house school indigenous of PROX | \glt ‘If only there were an indigenous school here!’

Knowledge Point: As the examples above show, the locative adjunct in these constructions is often introduced by to (in older Rapa Nui) or o (in modern Rapa Nui)\is{to (possessive prep.)}.\footnote{\label{fn:475}To is a contraction of the article te + the genitive preposition o (\sectref{sec:6.2}).} The possessive preposition\is{o (possessive prep.)} o, when used in a locative construction, often indicates that a referent belongs to a certain place, i.e. comes from that place or is located there permanently. It may, however, also indicate the location of a referent at a given moment, and therefore be similar in sense to \textit{{\ꞌ}i} (see (\ref{ex:6.44}–\ref{ex:6.46} in \sectref{sec:6.3.1}).
Content 1: \gll Te me\ꞌe nei he heke, he \ꞌanimare e tahi \textbf{o} \textbf{rote} \textbf{vaikava}. | \gls ART thing PROX PRED octopus PRED animal NUM one of inside_the ocean | \glt ‘The octopus is an animal of (lit. of inside) the ocean.’
Content 2: \gll Ko Alfredo te me\ꞌe era \textbf{o} \textbf{mu\ꞌa} i te microfono. | \gls PROM Alfredo ART thing DIST of front at ART microphone | \glt ‘Alfredo is the one in front of the microphone.’

Knowledge Point: In modern Rapa Nui, possessive clauses\is{Clause!possessive} are constructed as verbal existential clauses\is{Clause!existential}, in which the existential verb ai\is{ai ‘to exist’} takes the possessee as subject. \REF{ex:9.70} is literally ‘His house in Hanga Roa existed’, \REF{ex:9.71} is ‘Two their children existed’.
Content 1: \gll E ai rō \ꞌā tō\ꞌona hare \ꞌi Haŋa Roa. | \gls IPFV exist EMPH CONT POSS.3SG.O house at Hanga Roa | \glt ‘He had a house in Hanga Roa.’
Content 2: \gll He ai e rua rāua ŋā poki. | \gls NTR exist NUM two 3PL PL child | \glt ‘They had two children.’

Knowledge Point: As these examples show, the possessor\is{Possession} is expressed in the subject noun phrase: it is either a possessive pronoun as in (\ref{ex:9.70}–\ref{ex:9.71}), or a possessive noun phrase as in \REF{ex:9.72}. (For more details, see \sectref{sec:6.2.1} on possessives in the noun phrase, \sectref{sec:6.3.1} on the semantic range of possessive constructions, and \sectref{sec:6.3.2} on the choice between o and \textit{{\ꞌ}a}.)
Content 1: \gll E ai rō \ꞌā tō\ꞌona hare \ꞌi Haŋa Roa. | \gls IPFV exist EMPH CONT POSS.3SG.O house at Hanga Roa | \glt ‘He had a house in Hanga Roa.’
Content 2: \gll He ai e rua rāua ŋā poki. | \gls NTR exist NUM two 3PL PL child | \glt ‘They had two children.’
Content 3: \gll E ai rō \ꞌā te kona \ꞌoka mahute \ꞌa Kekepuē ko tetu. | \gls IPFV exist EMPH CONT ART place plant mulberry of.A Kekepue PROM huge | \glt ‘Kekepue had a huge plantation of mulberries.’

Knowledge Point: The clause may be preceded by a noun phrase coreferential to the possessor\is{Possession}; this happens especially when the possessor\is{Possession} is a full noun phrase. This noun phrase is left-dislocated\is{Dislocation!left} and is syntactically not a constituent of the clause that follows; the clause as a whole is a topic-comment construction (\sectref{sec:8.6.1.3}). \REF{ex:9.73} can be translated literally as ‘All the tribes, their leaders existed.’
Content 1: \gll \obTa\ꞌato\ꞌa mata\,\cb\textsubscripti e ai rō \ꞌana te rāua\textsubscripti taŋata pū\ꞌoko. | \gls {\db}all tribe IPFV exist EMPH CONT ART 3PL person head | \glt ‘All the tribes had their leaders.’

Knowledge Point: In these topic-comment\is{Topic-comment construction} constructions, the possessor\is{Possession} is often not expressed again in the subject NP. \REF{ex:9.75} is literally: ‘We, money exists’; \REF{ex:9.76} is ‘This woman, there were two daughters.’
Content 1: \gll \obA mātou\,\cb e ai nei te moni. | \gls {\db}PROP 1PL.EXCL IPFV exist PROX ART money | \glt ‘We have money.’
Content 2: \gll \obVi\ꞌe nei\,\cb e ai rō \ꞌā e rua poki vahine. | \gls {\db}woman PROX IPFV exist EMPH CONT NUM two child female | \glt ‘This woman had two daughters.’

Knowledge Point: As these examples show, in these cases the possessor\is{Possession} is a Ø-possessive\is{Pronoun!possessive!Ø-class} pronoun within the predicate noun phrase. These clauses are different from the old constructions illustrated in (\ref{ex:9.77}–\ref{ex:9.78}), where the possessor\is{Possession} is a separate constituent.\footnote{\label{fn:478}If the possessives in (\ref{ex:9.77}–\ref{ex:9.78}) were part of the predicate noun phrase, the possessor\is{Possession} would be marked with the preposition o in \REF{ex:9.77}, and a Ø-possessive\is{Pronoun!possessive!Ø-class} pronoun\is{Pronoun!possessive} in \REF{ex:9.78}.}
Content 1: \gll He \ꞌoka nō \textbf{to} \textbf{te} \textbf{hare}. | \gls PRED pole just ART:of ART house | \glt ‘The house had only rafters (no supporting poles).’
Content 2: \gll He poki \textbf{tā\ꞌana} e tahi, poki tamāroa. | \gls PRED child POSS.3SG.A NUM one child male | \glt ‘He had a child, a boy.’
Content 3: \gll He \ꞌoka nō \textbf{to} \textbf{te} \textbf{hare}. | \gls PRED pole just ART:of ART house | \glt ‘The house had only rafters (no supporting poles).’
Content 4: \gll He poki \textbf{tā\ꞌana} e tahi, poki tamāroa. | \gls PRED child POSS.3SG.A NUM one child male | \glt ‘He had a child, a boy.’
Content 5: \gll He \ꞌoka nō \textbf{to} \textbf{te} \textbf{hare}. | \gls PRED pole just ART:of ART house | \glt ‘The house had only rafters (no supporting poles).’
Content 6: \gll He poki \textbf{tā\ꞌana} e tahi, poki tamāroa. | \gls PRED child POSS.3SG.A NUM one child male | \glt ‘He had a child, a boy.’

Knowledge Point: Locative clauses consist of a subject noun phrase and a prepositional phrase with locative sense as predicate. Either phrase may come first. The locative phrase is often introduced by \textit{{\ꞌ}i}\is{i ‘in, at’@{\ꞌ}i ‘in, at’}, marking stationary location, possibly followed by a locational\is{Locational} as in \REF{ex:9.81}. Other prepositions may also be used, as \REF{ex:9.83} shows.
Content 1: \gll A nua \textbf{\ꞌi} \textbf{roto} i te hare. | \gls PROP Mum at inside at ART house | \glt ‘Mum is in the house.’
Content 2: \gll —¿\textbf{Mai} hē rā koe? —\textbf{Mai} tai nei. | \gls ~~~~from CQ INTENS 2SG ~~~from sea PROX | \glt ‘—Where are you (coming) from? —From the seaside.’

Knowledge Point: As these examples show, the predicate may come after the subject as in (\ref{ex:9.84}–\ref{ex:9.85}), or before the subject as in (\ref{ex:9.86}–\ref{ex:9.87}).
Content 1: \gll Te hare nei, ta\ꞌe ō\ꞌoku; o tā\ꞌaku mā\ꞌaŋa ena ko Puakiva. | \gls ART house PROX CONNEG POSS.1SG.O of POSS.1SG.A adopted_child MED PROM Puakiva | \glt ‘This house is not mine; it belongs to my adopted child Puakiva.’
Content 2: \gll A \ꞌĀrahu o te mata era o te Tūpāhotu. | \gls PROP Arahu of ART tribe DIST of ART Tupahotu | \glt ‘Arahu was of the Tupahotu tribe.’
Content 3: \gll \ꞌĀ\ꞌana ho\ꞌi te uka era, \ꞌa Métraux. | \gls POSS.3SG.A indeed ART girl DIST of.A Métraux | \glt ‘That girl belongs to him, Métraux.’
Content 4: \gll Ō\ꞌoku mau \ꞌana te hape. | \gls POSS.1SG.O really IDENT ART fault | \glt ‘The fault is really mine.’

Knowledge Point: Occasionally, proprietary clauses\is{Clause!proprietary} are constructed with the locative preposition i\is{i (preposition)}, which may have a possessive sense (\sectref{sec:4.7.2.3}). I in proprietary clauses\is{Clause!proprietary} tends to indicate possession in an abstract sense, e.g. possession of qualities or attributes; however, as \REF{ex:9.89} shows, it is also used with concrete entities.
Content 1: \gll I a mātou te kai ko piropiro \ꞌā. | \gls at PROP 1PL.EXCL ART food PRF rotten:RED CONT | \glt ‘Ours is the rotten food.’

Knowledge Point: Any prepositional phrase may serve as the predicate of a nominal clause\is{Clause!nominal}. This results in clauses that could be labelled “benefactive” \REF{ex:9.90}, “instrumental” \REF{ex:9.91} or “comparative\is{Comparative}” \REF{ex:9.92}; however, these labels should not obscure the fact that these clauses simply follow the general pattern of a NP PP clause.
Content 1: \gll Te haŋa o te hānau \ꞌe\ꞌepe \textbf{mō\ꞌona} te kāiŋa nei. | \gls ART want of ART race corpulent BEN.3SG.O ART homeland PROX | \glt ‘What the ‘corpulent race’ wanted was, that the island should be for them.’
Content 2: \gll Tō\ꞌona orara\ꞌa \textbf{hai} pura pere Tomatō. | \gls POSS.3SG.O living INS only play toma_todo | \glt ‘His living was (=he earned his living) merely by playing toma todo (a card game).’
Content 3: \gll A kōrua ta\ꞌe mau \ꞌana \textbf{pē} Kava. | \gls PROP 2PL CONNEG really IDENT like Kava | \glt ‘You are not really like Kava.’

Knowledge Point: As with all types of nominal clauses\is{Clause!nominal}, the constituent order is not fixed, though the subject tends to come first, as (\ref{ex:9.90}–\ref{ex:9.92}) show.
Content 1: \gll Te haŋa o te hānau \ꞌe\ꞌepe \textbf{mō\ꞌona} te kāiŋa nei. | \gls ART want of ART race corpulent BEN.3SG.O ART homeland PROX | \glt ‘What the ‘corpulent race’ wanted was, that the island should be for them.’
Content 2: \gll A kōrua ta\ꞌe mau \ꞌana \textbf{pē} Kava. | \gls PROP 2PL CONNEG really IDENT like Kava | \glt ‘You are not really like Kava.’

Knowledge Point: The following sentence, which is superficially almost identical to \REF{ex:9.93}, has a fundamentally different structure.
Content 1: \gll \obE tahi\,\cb \obte rāua poki vahine nehenehe\,\cb. | \gls {\db}NUM one {\db}ART 3PL child female beautiful | \glt ‘They had one beautiful daughter (lit. one [was] their beautiful daughter).’

Knowledge Point: Numerical clauses are not very common. It is more common for a numeral to be embedded within a noun phrase, as in \REF{ex:9.95} above. This is also illustrated in (\ref{ex:9.60}–\ref{ex:9.62}) in \sectref{sec:9.3.1}.
Content 1: \gll E tahi rāua poki vahine nehenehe. | \gls NUM one 3PL child female beautiful | \glt ‘They had one beautiful daughter (lit. one their beautiful daughter).’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{He} \textbf{repa} e rua te \ꞌīŋoa ko Makita ko Roke\ꞌaua. | \gls NTR young_man NUM two ART name PROM Makita PROM Roke’aua | \glt ‘There were two young men, named Makita and Roke’aua.’
Content 3: \gll E ai rō \ꞌā e tahi poki nei te \ꞌīŋoa ko Mariki. | \gls IPFV exist EMPH CONT NUM one child PROX ART name PROM Mariki | \glt ‘There was a child called Mariki.’

Subsection: Ai ‘to exist’ as a copula verb\label{sec:9.6.1
Knowledge Point: In (\ref{ex:9.99}–\ref{ex:9.100}) it is clear that ai is not the predicate of the clause between brackets. Rather, ai is an (existential) verb followed by a complete (independent) clause.\footnote{\label{fn:481}See further \sectref{sec:11.5.1.1} (mo) \sectref{sec:11.5.2.2} (ana) on the use of ai with subordinating markers.} The same analysis is possible for \REF{ex:9.97} above; in that case koe he Kiritō is a complete (nominal) clause, in which ai does not play a role. The same is true for \REF{ex:9.98}. If this analysis is correct, ai in (\ref{ex:9.97}–\ref{ex:9.98}) is not a copula verb. A compelling reason to adopt this analysis of \REF{ex:9.97} is, that the subject of a verb marked with mo is normally expressed as a possessive (\sectref{sec:11.5.1.2}). The fact that the subject in \REF{ex:9.97} is nominative koe, makes it an unlikely candidate for the subject position of the mo-clause.
Content 1: \gll Mo \textbf{ai} \obkai oho \ꞌā koe ki te kona roaroa...\,\cb | \gls if exist {\db}NEG.PFV go CONT 2SG to ART place far:RED | \glt ‘If you haven’t been to distant places (lit. if it is you haven’t gone)...’
Content 2: \gll ¡E u\ꞌi he ra\ꞌe ana \textbf{ai} \obe haŋa rō te taŋata\,\cb! | \gls ~EXH look NTR first IRR exist {\db}IPFV want EMPH ART person | \glt ‘First you must see whether the people want it (lit. whether it is the people want).’
Content 3: \gll Mo \textbf{ai} koe he Kiritō... | \gls if exist 2SG PRED Christ | \glt ‘If you are the Christ...’
Content 4: \gll \ꞌIna te \ꞌAtua he tapa atu ana \textbf{ai} koe he hūrio \ꞌo ta\ꞌe he hūrio. | \gls NEG ART God PRED consider away IRR exist 2SG PRED Jew or CONNEG PRED Jew | \glt ‘God does not consider whether you are a Jew or not a Jew.’
Content 5: \gll Mo \textbf{ai} koe he Kiritō... | \gls if exist 2SG PRED Christ | \glt ‘If you are the Christ...’
Content 6: \gll \ꞌIna te \ꞌAtua he tapa atu ana \textbf{ai} koe he hūrio \ꞌo ta\ꞌe he hūrio. | \gls NEG ART God PRED consider away IRR exist 2SG PRED Jew or CONNEG PRED Jew | \glt ‘God does not consider whether you are a Jew or not a Jew.’
Content 7: \gll Mo \textbf{ai} koe he Kiritō... | \gls if exist 2SG PRED Christ | \glt ‘If you are the Christ...’
Content 8: \gll Mo \textbf{ai} koe he Kiritō... | \gls if exist 2SG PRED Christ | \glt ‘If you are the Christ...’

Subsection: Ai ‘to exist’ as a copula verb\label{sec:9.6.1
Knowledge Point: In other cases, however, the analysis above is implausible. First, the subject after mo ai may be expressed as a possessive, strongly suggesting that it is indeed the subject of the mo{}-clause, hence an argument of ai. This suggests that ai in \REF{ex:9.101} is bivalent (hence copular), taking two arguments just like the transitive\is{Verb!transitive} verb \textit{{\ꞌ}ui} in \REF{ex:9.102}.
Content 1: \gll Mo \textbf{ai} \obō\ꞌou\,\cb \obhe Kiritō\,\cb, ka kī mai. | \gls if exist {\db}POSS.2SG.O {\db}PRED Christ IMP say hither | \glt ‘If you are the Christ, say so.’
Content 2: \gll he kona mo \textbf{\ꞌui} \obō\ꞌou\,\cb \obi ta\ꞌa me\ꞌe ta\ꞌe \ꞌite\,\cb | \gls PRED place for ask {\db}POSS.2SG.O {\db}ACC POSS.2SG.A thing CONNEG know | \glt ‘a place for you to ask the things you don’t know’

Subsection: Ai ‘to exist’ as a copula verb\label{sec:9.6.1
Knowledge Point: Second, a copular analysis of ai is plausible when it occurs in a main clause. Although \REF{ex:9.103} below could be interpreted as existential ai, this is not very plausible, as there are no unambiguous examples of ai in main clauses followed by an independent clause expressing the Existee. A monovalent analysis is even less likely when the two noun phrases occur on either side of the verb, as in \REF{ex:9.104}.
Content 1: \gll E ai \obkōrua\,\cb \obhe nu\ꞌu \ꞌina e tahi hape\,\cb. | \gls EXH exist {\db}2PL {\db}PRED people NEG NUM one fault | \glt ‘You should be people without fault.’
Content 2: \gll \obTu\ꞌu nu\ꞌu ena\,\cb he ai \obhe nu\ꞌu ō\ꞌoku\,\cb. | \gls {\db}POSS.2SG.O people MED NTR exist {\db}PRED people POSS.1SG.O | \glt ‘Your people will be my people.’

Subsection: Ai ‘to exist’ as a copula verb\label{sec:9.6.1
Knowledge Point: We may conclude that ai is occasionally used as a copula verb. Using ai enables a speaker to embed nominal clauses\is{Clause!nominal} into constructions which only allow verbal clauses, for example subordinate clauses as in \REF{ex:9.101}, and exhortations as in \REF{ex:9.103}.
Content 1: \gll Mo \textbf{ai} \obō\ꞌou\,\cb \obhe Kiritō\,\cb, ka kī mai. | \gls if exist {\db}POSS.2SG.O {\db}PRED Christ IMP say hither | \glt ‘If you are the Christ, say so.’
Content 2: \gll E ai \obkōrua\,\cb \obhe nu\ꞌu \ꞌina e tahi hape\,\cb. | \gls EXH exist {\db}2PL {\db}PRED people NEG NUM one fault | \glt ‘You should be people without fault.’

Knowledge Point: Riro occurs in a few stories in which a person turns into an animal. In older versions of these stories, the process of transformation is implicit and the new identity is expressed by a non-verbal clause; in new versions, riro is used. The following examples are from two versions of the same story, which tells about a child turning into a fish. In the old version in \REF{ex:9.106}, no verb is used to describe the transformation; the new version in \REF{ex:9.107} employs the verb riro.
Content 1: \gll He uru mai te e\ꞌa, he to\ꞌo i tau poki era. \textbf{He} \textbf{ika} tau poki era. | \gls NTR enter hither ART wave NTR take ACC DEM child DIST PRED fish DEM child DIST | \glt ‘A wave came in and took the child. The child (became) a fish.’
Content 2: \gll He \textbf{riro} rō atu \ꞌai tū poki era he ika. | \gls NTR become EMPH away SUBS DEM child DIST PRED fish | \glt ‘The child became a fish.’

Knowledge Point: As \REF{ex:9.107} shows, the verb riro has two arguments: the subject tū poki era and a he\is{he (nominal predicate marker)}{}-marked noun phrase expressing the class to which the subject belongs after the transformation. Apart from the verb, the clause has the same structure as the verbless classifying clause\is{Clause!classifying} in \REF{ex:9.106}. This shows that riro is a true copula verb, linking two noun phrases with an identity relation. Two more examples of the same construction:
Content 1: \gll He \textbf{riro} rō atu \ꞌai tū poki era he ika. | \gls NTR become EMPH away SUBS DEM child DIST PRED fish | \glt ‘The child became a fish.’
Content 2: \gll He uru mai te e\ꞌa, he to\ꞌo i tau poki era. \textbf{He} \textbf{ika} tau poki era. | \gls NTR enter hither ART wave NTR take ACC DEM child DIST PRED fish DEM child DIST | \glt ‘A wave came in and took the child. The child (became) a fish.’

Knowledge Point: While the form and meaning of riro were borrowed from \ili{Tahitian}\is{Tahitian influence}, its status as a copula verb is unique to Rapa Nui.\footnote{\label{fn:482}There is one possible exception: for \ili{Hawaiian}, \citet[63]{Cook1999} gives an example from an old text (1918) where he (which is a nominal predicate marker, as in Rapa Nui) marks the resulting entity after the verb lilo, an argument normally marked with i (related to \ili{Tahitian} \textit{{\ꞌ}ei} in \REF{ex:9.110}?). Apparently, this construction, which corresponds exactly to the Rapa Nui construction riro he, is unknown nowadays.} In \ili{Tahitian}, the resulting entity after riro is marked with the preposition \textit{{\ꞌ}ei}:\footnote{\label{fn:483}\ili{Tahitian} \textit{{\ꞌ}ei} has various uses, all of which have to do with a state not yet realised; see \citet[364–365]{AcadémieTahitienne1986}.}
Content 1: Not found
